clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Respiratory Acoustic Monitor in Children After Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Respiratory Acoustic Monitor in Children After Surgery

collaborator.agency: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

brief_summary.textblock: The study will evaluate the performance of measuring respiration rate with the Respiratory Acoustic Monitoring (RAM).

detailed_description.textblock: The study seeks to determine the reliability and accuracy of the acoustic respiratory monitoring (RAM) in comparison of clinically completed transthoracic impedance monitoring (TI) and manual counting of respiratory rate in postoperative pediatric patients at risk of adverse respiratory events.

primary_outcome.measure: Reliability/ accuracy of respiratory acoustic monitoring (RAM)
primary_outcome.description: The respiratory acoustic monitor records three vital signs: Respiration rate will be recorded in breaths per minute, oxygen saturation will be recorded in percentage, and heart rate will be recorded in beats per minute. The reliability and accuracy of data collected by the RAM will be examined by comparing to data collected clinically. The data obtained from RAM will be compared to both clinical methods: transthoracic impedance and manual counting of respirations. The accuracy of RAM will also be examined when a staff member goes back into the RAM recordings to manually count respirations during 10% of data collected on each patient. These numbers will be compared to the the actual data provided by the RAM.

secondary_outcome.measure: Causes of unreliability and low accuracy of RAM and transthoracic impedance
secondary_outcome.description: The causes of signal drop off of the RAM and transthoracic impedance will be recorded. Items causing signal drop off could include computer failure or lack of patient tolerance.
The presence of false alarms with the RAM and transthoracic impedance will occur with the assessment of the first aarm of an every two-hour random sample of the recorded respiratory rates.

secondary_outcome.measure: Tolerance of the RAM and transthoracic impedance pads
secondary_outcome.description: The tolerance is defined as the ratio of the time the sensor stays in place divided by the total expected time of monitoring

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of low oxygen and heart rate
secondary_outcome.description: The incidence of low oxygen and heart rate will be recorded by pulse oximetry data.

arm_group.description: All participants will wear the respiratory acoustic monitoring device.

intervention.description: Examine the reliability and accuracy of the respiratory acoustic monitor.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male or female children 2 to 16 years of age
- In-patients or 23 hour short stay patients who had a tonsillectomy with a diagnosis or symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea or who had any surgery and receiving an opioid by patient controlled analgesia for post-operative pain control
- Child weighs at least 10 kg on day of surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient has skin abnormalities (rash, eczema, etc.) at the planned application sites that would interfere with sensor or electrode applications.
- Patient is admitted to the Intensive Care Unit
- Patient has tracheostomy
- Patient is on non-invasive ventilator support
